previous_statement: IMPLICATION (2)⟹(3) CONCLUSION: Since G preserves no non-trivial partition, B is trivial: either B = {α} or B = Ω. If B = {α}, then H·α = {α}, so H = G_α. If B = Ω, then H acts transitively, so H = G (since G is transitive). Hence G_α is maximal.
new_statement: IMPLICATION (2)⟹(3) CONCLUSION: Since G preserves no non-trivial partition, B is trivial. Case B={α}: Then H·α={α}, so H stabilizes α, hence H ≤ G_α. With G_α ≤ H, we get H = G_α. Case B=Ω: By Block_Stabilizer_Correspondence, there is a bijection K ↔ K·α between subgroups G_α ≤ K ≤ G and blocks containing α. Since G·α = Ω (G transitive) and H·α = Ω, bijectivity gives H = G. Hence G_α is maximal.
